column2: I understand that contributed datasets will be made available under a CC-BY or similar license. This means that the COSORE database will be open without restriction to the science community; we strongly encourage database users to cite original publications and offer co-authorship, but it's not required.
column3: I have all necessary authority and permissions (legal or otherwise) to provide these data to the COSORE database.
column4: Once we've worked through the metadata below, we'll send you a custom data upload link.
column5: COSORE is a community database, and will always be open...but it's not an institutionally-backed repository like Figshare, DataONE, ESS-DIVE, etc. We recommend depositing your data in one of these first, and providing its DOI below. NOTE: you can do this for free through services like https://figshare.com/

column19: Coastal Sage Scrub (CSS) vegetation is dominated by the native shrubs Artemisia californica, Eriogonum fasciculatum and Salvia mellifera; intershrub spaces contain invasive annual grasses Bromus madritensis var. rubens and forbs Centaurea solstitialis and Hirschfeldia incana
column24: This data was originally collected and analysed by Marguerite Mauritz and David Lipson to investigate soil respiration patterns in semi-arid shrubland invaded by annual grasses and forbs. The LI-8100 was kindly loaned by Walt Oechel.

Two things to consider: 
1. We have continuous data from 2004-2015 for six chambers. However, we have done the root trenching experiment during 2013–15 for three chambers.
2. David Hollinger (site PI) is the contact person for ancillary dataset (other than soil temperature and soil moisture). Should this be considered for the "contributor(s)" section?

column24: Those who intend to use the continuous soil respiration dataset from the Harvard forest site for their research are strongly encouraged to contact and acknowledge the contributors listed above.
column48:
We have automated data from the control (2012-2014) and root-trenched (2013-2014) chambers from US-Ha1 (EMS tower site). Additionally, we have automated chamber data from different stands withing Harvard forest for three more years (2003, 2009, and 2010) with different treatments (trenching, rainfall exclusion, root exudation etc) based on different research objectives in each study. 

We have soil temperature and soil moisture data for all chambers. Other ancillary data are generally available from the Harvard Forest LTER website.

column48:
Soil chamber arrays are located along a ridge-slope-valley topographic gradient. So, "elevation" gradient ranged between 350 to 1075 m. Because the google doc file won't allow to submit a range, I have given the "range" of elevation from valley to ridge here.

We have hourly soil respiration data for the entire length. But, soil temperature, soil moisture, and oxygen values are not coupled with individual soil chambers. Rather sensor data are available along the topographic gradient on seven positions. I haven't added those here. But, I can couple mean (and SD) of chamber data with mean (and SD) of sensor data for daily-average values. Should that be acceptable?

column48: (1) Only the small plants on the surface were removed. All the deep plant roots were kept alive in the chambers. (2) When the site was flooded, the volume of the collar space varied, so the raw LI-8100 flux data were corrected with the water table depth data. (3) The ancillary site data include 5-cm soil temperature (Ts) and water table depth (WTD). (4) In the 30-min data, FLAG of 1 means gap-filled data and 0 the raw measurements.

column48: Spikes in soil respiration were detected and removed. We computed the mean and standard deviation for a series of moving windows of length L (here L=24, equals two days data). The window moves one data point at a time through the series. Any data in the window that exceeds 3.5 standard deviation is considered as a spike and replaced with NaN.

column24:
The first 2 years of soil respiration data (2014 and 2015) were previously published (https://doi.org/10.1007/s10533-018-0457-7).
Data were collected at the Cumberland Plain Australian Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network (TERN) site, which encompasses EucFACE and the flux tower. The Cumberland Plain TERN facilities are supported by the Australian Government through the Education Investment Fund, the Department of Industry and Science, the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy, and the Australian Research Council in partnership with Western Sydney University. Facilities at EucFACE were built as an initiative of the Australian Government as part of the Nation-building Economic Stimulus Package.

column48: These data are from a whole-ecosystem warming experiment. Each collar was in a sunlit, climate controlled chamber that was either held at ambient temperature, warmed symetrically (+3.5 degrees day and night) or warmed asymetrically (+5C at dawn, decreasing to +2C at mid-afternoon). There are 12 collars representing 4 replicates per treatment.
